title: René Lezard logo/Aledux
content:
Can anyone identify these two fonts?

The first font is from the René Lezard logotype.

The closest match of the second one (typeface02.jpg) I found was the "Latin wide" (from Castle Type) [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-wide-ct/latin-wide/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113233523/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-wide-ct/latin-wide/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-wide-ct/latin-wide/") , but the "Latin Wide" is heavier, less elegant and more extended than the one on the picture...

Thanks.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [typeface01.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113233523/http:/typophile.com/files/typeface01.jpg) | 36.48 KB |
| [typeface02.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113233523/http:/typophile.com/files/typeface02.jpg) | 26.1 KB |
author: urban_one

comments.content:
Don't you think these might very well be custom designed logos? What better way to protect your brand than to make it _really_ hard to forge your logo?

Anyone else has an idea?

Yeh, I know they might be customised. But as we all have got a "mother" and a "father", I guess these customised typefaces must have roots as well. I don't think they came completely out of the blue. So I'd even be happy to know the roots of these types. Suggestions welcome...

_\> I guess these customised typefaces must have roots as well._

Well, that's the whole point -- they're _not_ customised existing fonts, but custom designed logos, which means it's less obvious to find a "master" design. They might be based on a certain type style, but not necessarily on a specific typeface.
